metadata.title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
metadata.author: Shirley Jackson

knowledge_zone.heading: Symbolism: Deeper meaning through symbolic objects/actions

sections.content: Symbolism is used throughout the text to deeper meaning through symbolic objects/actions.

examples.quote: the crack in the sidewalk that looked
examples.scene: Merricat noting the pointing crack as a permanent landmark
examples.effect: The crack represents the unchanging nature of the village's hostility and serves as a physical marker of Merricat's traumatic journey

examples.quote: All our land was enriched with my treasures buried in it
examples.scene: Merricat describes her burial rituals and protective objects
examples.effect: Buried items symbolize Merricat's psychological need for control, presented as rational protection through her distorted lens

examples.quote: We are on the moon at last
examples.scene: Merricat and Constance in their forest hideout
examples.effect: The moon represents complete isolation from society - Merricat's fantasy of escape becomes literal reality as they retreat from the world

pedagogy_zone.heading: From Device Spotting to Analysis
pedagogy_zone.intro_text: Most students can identify a device. Strong analysis shows what it DOES. Don't just label it—explain its function in creating meaning.

content.question: Ask yourself: Why does the author use Symbolism HERE? What meaning does it create in this specific moment?
content.framework: Use TVODE: Technique → Verb → Observation → Device effect → Evaluation

pedagogy_zone.essay_application: In your essays, always connect device to meaning. Show HOW the technique creates the effect, don't just identify that it's there.
